author: MENAFN
title: Israel Launches Fresh Missile Attack On Targets Near Syrian Capital | MENAFN.COM
text:
( MENAFN - IANS) Damascus, Dec 29 (IANS) A fresh Israeli missile attack targetted the outskirts of the Syrian capital of Damascus, triggering a response from the Syrian air defence system, the media reported.
The Syrian army said on Thursday in a statement that the "Israeli enemy" carried out an aerial attack from the direction of the occupied Syrian Golan Heights, targetting some points in the southern region, without elaborating on the targeted sites.
It added that the Syrian air defence forces intercepted most of them, with losses limited to material damages.
Previous Israeli strikes in Syria had reportedly targetted military sites suspected of harbouring Iranian-backed militias, arms convoys, and alleged weapons storage facilities, according to the opposition watchdog group -- the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.
Israel has recently upped its attacks on Syrian targets in tandem with its military campaign in the Gaza Strip, Xinhua news agency reported.
Syria has been engulfed in over 12-year war, with the government forces of President Bashar al-Assad, backed by Russia and Iran, fighting against various opposition groups.
Israel, on the other hand, has a long-standing policy of preventing Iran from establishing a military presence in Syria by repeatedly conducting airstrikes to destroy alleged Iranian weapons supplies.
The previous Israeli attack in Syria on Monday evening killed Seyyed Razi Mousavi, who was also one of the longest-serving advisors of Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) in Syria and a close associate of the late Iranian top commander Qassem Soleimani, who was assassinated by a US drone attack in Iraq in 2020.
--IANS
int/khz
MENAFN28122023000231011071ID1107666772

author: Matt Swayne
title: Superposition Guy Podcast ‚Äî Ryan Lafler, Quantum Corridor
text:
Ryan Lafler, President and CTO of Quantum Corridor, is interviewed by Yuval Boger. Ryan highlights Quantum Corridor‚Äôs development of a 12-mile fiber network in the Midwest, designed for quantum and classical computing. The network, connecting major data centers, focuses on quantum communications and research, with a capacity of 40 terabits per second. Ryan discusses collaborations, such as with Toshiba Systems for quantum key distribution, emphasizes the strategic importance of the Midwest location, notes the project‚Äôs governmental support and its role in advancing global quantum technology competitiveness, and much more.
Listen:
Here.
Transcript:
Yuval Boger: Hello, Ryan. Thank you for joining me today.
Ryan Lafler: Thanks for having me. Appreciate it.
Yuval: Absolutely. So, who are you, and what do you do?
Ryan: So my name is Ryan Laffler. I‚Äôm the president and CTO and a co-founder of Quantum Corridor. I‚Äôm very happy to be supporting the scientific community and then also helping to eventually privatize and commercialize both quantum communications and also housing those that would want to prop up private industry with quantum technologies and help to commercialize.
Yuval: What does Quantum Corridor do, and what‚Äôs quantum about it?
Ryan: It‚Äôs a great question. Appreciate that. So, we‚Äôre an enabler of quantum technologies. So if you think of highways and you think of cars, what we‚Äôve constructed is a corridor where we‚Äôre going to be providing lanes of traffic. The applications, which will be the quantum technology, eventually the BB84 protocol and QKD are set to ride on top of our highway in the middle of 2024.
Yuval: I‚Äôm guessing that includes a data center or more than one data centers‚Ä¶
Ryan: It does. So the head end of our network starts at what‚Äôs one of the largest Internet exchanges in the world, which is 350 CERMAC in the heart of Chicago. And it also spans down to another data center, which is in northwest Indiana at 100 Digital Crossroad. And what that includes is a 12-mile stretch of what was initially dark fiber. And then we‚Äôre tying into a couple other key education institutions and universities to establish a research corridor. So part of the lanes of traffic that we‚Äôre providing and I refer to is going to be for research and development. Part of the network that we‚Äôre building is going to be for commercial traffic. And then there‚Äôs going to be a part of the network that we‚Äôre building that‚Äôs going to be a combination of both. So you have private industry that‚Äôs meeting research and development and then, of course, all these applications and quantum computers need a home where we will be providing critical infrastructure for them to house the R&D that will be going on on a physical infrastructure level.
Yuval: Is this a regional network for now?
Ryan: It is. It‚Äôs operating across state lines between Chicago, Illinois and Indiana. Given that it‚Äôs regional, what would the ideal user or customer of the service be? So it can run the gamut. So we have a bioscience, life sciences that have been very interested. Obviously quantum communications, which is what we‚Äôre enabling, is coupled with a couple different things. So we have an incredible throughput level. We were one of the fastest networks in the Western hemisphere, aside from the likes of an EOSnet, for example, that would be 100% dedicated to research. We‚Äôre 40 terabits per second. And if you were to go onto Google and type, ‚ÄúWell, who‚Äôs the fastest network in the world?‚Äù It would say, ‚ÄúESnet, at least in that Western hemisphere, which is 46 terabits.‚Äù We‚Äôre 6 terabits slower, but they‚Äôre 100% dedicated to research. And so we want to enable both research and private industry on our corridors. So the tie-in would be research institutions, to answer your question. And then also, as you‚Äôre aware, quantum is kind of the Cold War technology race of our time. So you have a lot of the hyperscale chips that are trying to get an extreme light up on that race. A lot of QKD has been tested in principle. It‚Äôs been tested inside the lab. But what our asset‚Äôs offering is the ability to test this in a real-world environment, with real-world attenuations along highways and along rail systems. And so what we hope to be is one of the first networks in the world that‚Äôs enabling QKD and BB84 protocol, even post-quantum cryptography in real time on our network. And so what we want to do is go to those hyperscalers, chip manufacturers, education research firms, and life sciences, biosciences, and say, ‚ÄúHey, we have a facility that will house you. We can meet all of your infrastructure needs. And then, by the way, we offer this 12-mile stretch of a research network and private network where we can actually push these quantum protocols in real time over our network.‚Äù
Yuval: Why the Midwest? I mean, I‚Äôm calling you today from the Midwest as well. But why set up such a quantum corridor in the Midwest?
Ryan: Well, it‚Äôs not because of the weather. So we have a really ripe environment here. We‚Äôve got the likes of Fermilabs, for example. We‚Äôve got Argonne. We‚Äôve got Chicago Quantum Exchange, for example, that are here. There‚Äôs obviously a TechHub designation that‚Äôs just been awarded because of the interest of the University of Chicago and quantum exchange. There‚Äôs incredible access to fresh water that we have that we can tie into. And then there‚Äôs the cross-state initiatives from Illinois to Indiana where we have Purdue and we have Purdue Northwest and we have Notre Dame that we can tie in together. So the way that we looked at this is that there‚Äôs a lot of disparate players that are out there state by state. And what we want to do is we want to unite all of these institutions in the spirit of collaboration. So that‚Äôs key. And then when you look at available land, and you look at available power, and you look at fresh water that‚Äôs next to the lake, we can meet all of these parameters easily. And then you don‚Äôt have environmental factors as many environmental factors like earthquakes would be on the West Coast, for example. So we really feel that with all those things, we have an environment here that‚Äôs really right to kick this off to the next level.
Yuval: Can you give me some examples of customers or organizations that are already using your services?
Ryan: Yeah. So this is really early on. So, we just announced and tested our network about four weeks ago. This has been a partnership with Sienna, who is the first to shoot light across this network. We are currently in talks with Toshiba Systems about bolting on their application and testing QKD with us in the middle of 2024. There are also some research institutions, which I can‚Äôt at this time name, that will be testing their gear across our network. And then we are actively entering into MOU with some top chip manufacturers and hyperscalers that I also can‚Äôt name because of NDAs that will be pushing across our network. One thing that I can tell you is that there‚Äôs a very, very real interest in being able to spread out in a distributed or edge-computing fashion along the corridor. Historically, a lot of this research was done at universities, which is great, but the participation with private industry is really what‚Äôs driving this. It‚Äôs kind of a first for this industry where we‚Äôre kind of entering a world of commercial. So it‚Äôs a very, very exciting time, and we can help our partners enable that.
Yuval: I understand the bandwidth uniqueness. You mentioned the 46 versus 40 earlier in our conversation. But there are national and even international or even global service providers for connectivity. What are the unique requirements that cause you to set up this separate entity?
Ryan: Well, in regards to quantum, the first thing that I‚Äôll say is classical networking is not able to transmit QKE and BB84 protocol. It‚Äôs common knowledge that only two current networks can do this. And so when we came across the white paper that was published in tandem with Ciena, JPMorgan Chase, and Toshiba Systems and was released in 2022, we realized that something very special was going on. They announced the first QKD transmissions that took place in North America in that white paper. And we contacted Ciena and Converge One, and we said to them, ‚ÄúCan we be that environment that‚Äôs real world that you guys would like to test this on? Here‚Äôs the dark fiber asset that we have currently and that we can offer. It‚Äôs all American-made glass. It‚Äôs just three spins and splices. We‚Äôre operating in an optimal decibel loss range to complete this.‚Äù And that‚Äôs where the conversation started to become very real about pointing to a reconfigurable line system coherent network.
And that‚Äôs basically the premise in layman‚Äôs terms of you‚Äôve got all these bands. You‚Äôve got all these different laser lights that we are pushing data systems within traditional DWDM, but Coherence, the premise of combining all those waves of light into one large wavelength. And so part of what we‚Äôre doing there is that we‚Äôre supporting an incredible throughput that kind of makes us like other networks in the world. However, I would argue in most cases, it is faster with the 40 terabits, a quarter of a millisecond latencies. But the other side of that, so that enables all kinds of really, really cool things with technology, obviously. But the other side to that is that we‚Äôre able to enable BB84 and QKD on top of our network. If you think about quantum technology and quantum computers in general, it‚Äôs unlike traditional compute because in traditional compute, computers aren‚Äôt smart; they‚Äôre just fast. You‚Äôre solving problems through rapid trial and error. So, with quantum communications, it‚Äôs the possibility of exploring every scenario all at one time and instantaneously. So you need a network that‚Äôs capable of transmitting that if these quantum computers and the research institutions are going to collaborate. And so you can‚Äôt have multiple sessions going really, really fast on traditional DWDM networks. You need coherent communications to support all states at all times across these communication nodes, back from where we‚Äôre housing this infrastructure to these research institutions that we‚Äôll be transmitting and receiving. There‚Äôs a kind of quantum version of the space race between various countries and regions.
Yuval: How does what you‚Äôre offering compare in terms of both the investment and the capabilities to what you‚Äôre seeing in Europe, China, Australia, or in other non-US regions?
Ryan: There‚Äôs a couple that I‚Äôm aware of that are doing what we‚Äôre doing. We are certainly, Yuval, on the leading edge of this. For example, in London, there‚Äôs a quantum loop project that‚Äôs going on in tandem with BT Telecom. In Quebec, there‚Äôs a quantum loop project. There are certainly small five-kilometer quantum projects that are going on even downstate in Urbana with UIC. And we respect those other players. We don‚Äôt necessarily see them as competition. We see them as collaborators, as we would in the normal communication world, just like the rail systems eventually connect to other rail systems to transport people. That‚Äôs the way that we want to plug in and we want to enable research in the Midwest. With that being said, we‚Äôre one of the few that are doing this in the Midwest. Certainly, there are traditional networks that have communication systems, but we‚Äôre one of the few that will be enabling quantum. And with the network that we‚Äôve already constructed and the relationships with the research institutions that we‚Äôre already taking on, and then also the interests with the block submission tech hub designation. We feel that we offer a really, really ripe environment to take the spirit of collaboration to the next level.
Yuval: You mentioned UIUC, and that‚Äôs one area where there‚Äôs a supercomputer or a supercomputing center. And many people think that quantum and classical computers will work together as opposed to just pure quantum or pure classical. How is your network geared to support that hybrid mode of operation?
Ryan: So we‚Äôll offer different segments of the network. One thing that we‚Äôre able to do with coherent technology is break off dedicated customer instances through wave servers. And so we say, okay, on this network, we‚Äôre going to carve you out a dedicated piece where we‚Äôre offering these lanes that can support these specific applications, whatever that is. Post-quantum cryptographic, BB84, QKD, we‚Äôre going to support that. Over here, we‚Äôre offering dedicated wave instances on our network that may be for your regular commercial traffic. For example, our latencies are such that we process data 500 times faster than a blink of an eye. Across state lines, we can transmit the entire Library of Congress in three seconds. The latency loss experience that you have from the largest internet exchange in the world to data centers that we house on the South Shore, across state lines in Indiana, is less than the latency between your TV and your cable. So these are all just relative examples that we put in perspective.
If you have one research institution that‚Äôs, let‚Äôs say in Chicago, you have another research institution that‚Äôs on the Indiana toll road 40 miles away, and you have supercomputers that are coming up with simulation modeling. Historically, they would have to stop their supercomputers from transmitting information to their colleagues 40 miles away and let the networks catch up. With the network that we‚Äôve created, what we‚Äôre out to do is greatly increase the efficiencies because if a near-instantaneous transmission of information is going from point to point, these supercomputers can keep chugging. So that‚Äôs what it‚Äôs going to do for traditional compute. And then for quantum compute, obviously, we‚Äôve already talked about kind of all states instantaneous information being exchanged. That‚Äôs how we‚Äôre going to prop up both sides of the fence. So to answer your question, we‚Äôve got a solution for traditional DWDM type customers. We‚Äôve got a solution for quantum customers, and that traffic will literally be segmented. And that‚Äôs part of the security in our offering that we‚Äôre putting out there as well.
Yuval: You mentioned the Library of Congress, and that brought Congress to my mind the National Quantum Initiative. How do you think the politicians, nationally or regionally, are attuned to the opportunity in quantum and the need to invest in centers like yours?
Ryan: So the Department of Defense is becoming very, very aware. This is the greatest technology race of our time. It‚Äôs the technological Cold War race of our time. Whoever achieves quantum supremacy is going to rule the world. I mean, we can all wrap our minds around scenarios where somebody goes and solves the blockchain in three seconds rather than 21 years, which these quantum computers will certainly be capable of. But maybe some people don‚Äôt think about the implications of us operating in 256-bit encryption, which also can be unlocked in seconds. National security agency secrets being exposed, nuclear codes leaking. Those are all the implications aside from just the financial system implications that this has. And so there‚Äôs a quantum readiness bill that‚Äôs clear in the hell and being adopted early in the spring. There are now billions of dollars being awarded in the tech hub designations that are going out, and they‚Äôre announcing regional tech hub designations. One that we‚Äôre a part of here in the Midwest. And then, you know, aside from that, there‚Äôs the traditional stimulus monies that have been propping up some aspects of networks and infrastructure that needs to go into this.
Pritzker himself, when we‚Äôre talking about state government, is committing $300 million to this region. He‚Äôs been instrumental in propping up the Asholom Research Center that‚Äôs here with the University of Chicago. And is very, very up on making Chicago and the Midwest a huge leader in this. On the other side of the fence, in Indiana, we‚Äôve got Eric Holcomb that‚Äôs propped us up through the Ready Grant. And purchasing of these optics, these RLX Flex-Cred Coherent Optics that we purchased through Indiana‚Äôs commitment to not just making this an Illinois thing but spanning this out along the corridor to tie Indiana‚Äôs research institutions into this. We see a multi-state collaboration, and government from local to state to federal has been involved. And I think we‚Äôre going to see a lot more of that involved.
Yuval: As we come closer to the end of our conversation. I‚Äôm curious, professionally speaking, what keeps you up at night?
Ryan: It‚Äôs making the right connections, and it‚Äôs capitalizing on opportunity. I mean, certainly, you know, there‚Äôs a collaborative spirit to all of this, but there‚Äôs a timeline. There‚Äôs a timeline that we have as a nation to get this right. And there are a lot of good people behind the scenes and that are part of our group and people that are smarter than me that have put a lifetime into getting us to where we are. So we‚Äôre standing on the shoulders of giants, and our opportunity is going to be connecting these people in the truest way. And we‚Äôre connecting networks to get these people to collaborate. But if we can‚Äôt accomplish that fast enough, and foreign interests do, that‚Äôs a real threat to everything that we‚Äôve worked on as a nation.
Yuval: And last hypothetical, if you could have dinner with one of the quantum greats, dead or alive, who would that person be?
Ryan: You know, I‚Äôve already had the opportunity to sit down with one of the great ones. I guess it wasn‚Äôt dinner, but you know, there‚Äôs a great scientist right here in our backyard. He‚Äôs a gentleman by the name of David Awschalom. And that was the Awschalom Research Institute I was talking about. It‚Äôs just incredible to pick the brains of the greats find out what their large-scale vision is for where they want to take this. So I‚Äôve been privileged to kind of be in the shadows of some of those individuals.
Yuval: Wonderful. Ryan, thank you so much for joining me today.
Ryan: Thank you for having me.
Yuval Boger is the chief marketing officer for
QuEra, the leader in neutral-atom quantum computers. Known as the ‚ÄúSuperposition Guy‚Äù as well as the original ‚ÄúQubit Guy,‚Äù he can be reached on [this email](/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#a0d3d5d0c5d2d0cfd3c9d4c9cfcec7d5d9e0c7cdc1c9cc8ec3cfcd9fd3d5c2cac5c3d49dc6d2cfcdfff1e3f2)
If you found this article to be informative, you can explore more current
quantum news here, exclusives, interviews, and podcasts.

title: Las redes sentencian de esta forma la Gala Inocente, Inocente en TVE
text: La Gala Inocente, Inocente 2023 tendr√° como objetivo ayudar a todos los ni√±os con enfermedades raras y sin diagn√≥stico en Espa√±a y a sus familias. Las nuevas ‚Äúv√≠ctimas‚Äù de las divertidas bromas de este a√±o ser√°n el futbolista √Ålvaro Morata, la comunicadora y presentadora Tania Llasera, el influencer Xuso Jones, el cantante Carlos Baute, el presentador Gonzalo Mir√≥ y el actor Jos√© Luis Garc√≠a P√©rez. La gala estar√° presentada por Cristinini, Juanma Iturriaga, Jacob Petrus y Carolina Casado. Contar√° con las actuaciones de Ana Guerra, Andr√©s Su√°rez, Varry Brava y N√≠a. Tambi√©n participar√° Wilbur, el simp√°tico acr√≥bata de ‚ÄòEl Grand Prix del Verano‚Äô, y habr√° muchas m√°s sorpresas. Tras 28 a√±os de emisi√≥n, la Gala Inocente pedir√° la colaboraci√≥n de los espectadores para ayudar a los menores con enfermedades raras. Se puede donar en la web de la Fundaci√≥n Inocente, llamando al 900 30 30 52, PayPal y a trav√©s de Bizum al 33379 En apoyo a las enfermedades raras Un a√±o m√°s, RTVE y la Fundaci√≥n Inocente dedican esta noche tan especial a colectivos con necesidades especiales, que este a√±o ser√°n los ni√±os con enfermedades raras (ER) y a sus familias. Las ER son aquellas que tienen una baja prevalencia en la poblaci√≥n, es decir, que afectan a menos de cinco personas por cada 10.000 habitantes. Sin embargo, tres millones de personas en Espa√±a conviven con una ER. El 70 % de estas enfermedades se desarrollan en la infancia y en la mitad de los casos el pron√≥stico vital est√° en juego. A las enfermedades raras se les puede atribuir el 35 % de las muertes de menores de un a√±o y el 10 % de las muertes de menores de entre uno y cinco a√±os. El diagn√≥stico tard√≠o, la dificultad del acceso al tratamiento y la merma de la calidad de vida son los mayores h√°ndicaps de los menores afectados. Estos ni√±os pueden presentar retraso en el crecimiento, complicaciones al andar o dificultad en el habla, entre otros problemas frecuentes. El pediatra, en los controles de salud, o los padres, suelen ser los primeros en darse cuenta de que algo no va bien‚Ä¶ por lo que se realizan visitas a diferentes especialistas para intentar obtener respuestas sobre lo que le pasa al peque√±o. Una respuesta que, debido a la complejidad y a la poca informaci√≥n sobre estas enfermedades, puede tardar a√±os en llegar.

author: Yahoo Sports Staff, Yahoo Sports
title: Alabama QB Jalen Milroe says former Crimson Tide OC Bill O'Brien told him he 'shouldn't play quarterback' ‚Äì WFTV
text:
Before returning to the NFL this season as New England's offensive coordinator, Bill O'Brien spent two seasons in the same position at Alabama.
Part of his tenure there was spent discouraging Jalen Milroe from playing quarterback. That's according to Milroe.
The Crimson Tide quarterback said so while speaking with reporters Thursday ahead of of Monday's national semifinal game against Michigan.
Alabama QB Jalen Milroe says his former OC and current Patriots OC Bill O'Brien told him he should not be a quarterback.
"How would you feel if I told you that you sucked?"
"Look where I'm at right now. So who gets the last laugh?" pic.twitter.com/xurEAr61ge
‚Äî Ari Meirov (@MySportsUpdate) December 28, 2023 "All my life, even when I was in college," Milroe said of people discouraging him from playing the position. "Shoot, my own offensive coordinator Bill O'Brien told me I shouldn't play quarterback."
Asked on a followup about his reaction to O'Brien's assessment, here's what Monroe had to say:
"How would you feel if I told you you suck?" Milroe said.
"I wouldn't like it," the reporter responded.
"Ok, then. That's exactly how I felt," Milroe continued. "Biggest thing for me, be true to myself and stay the same. Nothing changed about me. Only thing that changed was that I had opportunity, and I seized it."
Milroe went on to say that O'Brien told him "there's a bunch of positions" he could have switched to from quarterback.
"But look where I am right now," Milroe continued. "Who gets the last laugh?"
How Jalen Milroe got here Where Milroe is right now is in the College Football Playoff. But it wasn't a straight-forward path to get there.
Milroe took over at Alabama in the fall after 2021 Heisman Trophy winner Bryce Young left for the NFL as the No. 1 pick by the Carolina Panthers. His hold on the position was initially tenuous, and head coach Nick Saban benched him in Week 3 after he threw two interceptions in a Week 2 loss to Texas. His second interception set Texas up at the Alabama five-yard line ahead of a go-ahead touchdown in the fourth quarter.
But Milroe returned as Alabama's starter in Week 4 and has since led the Tide to 10 straight wins that included perhaps the pass of the college football season to beat Auburn ahead of victory over Georgia in the SEC championship. He finished the season completing 65.5% of his passes for 10.4 yards per attempt and 226.5 yards per game with 23 touchdowns and six interceptions. He added 468 yards and 12 touchdowns on the ground as one of college football's most dynamic offensive talents.
Now he's two wins away form a national championship. And he's not shy about letting his doubters know it.

title: Re Carlo Harry e Meghan Markle sempre pi√π distanti | la nuova foto su Instagram
text:
Re Carlo Harry e Meghan Markle sempre pi√π distanti | la nuova foto su Instagram
Mentre lo staff di Re Carlo va avanti nelle trattative con quello di Harry, Meghan Markle √É¬® sempre pi√É¬π distante dal marito. Dietro un√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢apparente convivenza serena, i Sussex vivrebbero vite separate. Cos√É¬¨, lei pubblica una nuova foto su Instagram con un ospite inaspettato e lui vola in Angola da solo. Ma procediamo con ordine. Re Carlo, le trattative con Harry proseguono. Stando a fonti vicine a Palazzo, un primo passo verso il disgelo tra Harry e Re Carlo √É¬® stato fatto e sta dando risultati positivi. Re Carlo non c√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢√É¬® pi√É¬π nulla da fare, Harry ricompare in pubblico dopo l√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢intervista bomba - Re Carlo e Harry non si riappacificheranno mai pi√É¬π. L√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢intervista bomba alla BBC ha sancito la fine di speranza di riconciliazione e come se nulla fosse il Duca del Sussex √É¬® ricomparso in pubblico a Las Vegas in occasione del Diana Award.

author: Saleen Martin
title: 'May this keep you safe from harm': WWII era Bible returned to New York veteran's family
text: Lost Bible returned to slain USAAF airman from World War II [Saleen Martin](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/7245115001/saleen-martin/) During World War II, a woman bought three brothers Bibles to protect their hearts and guide them as they set out for battle. The Bible had a metal cover on the front with the inscription ‚ÄúMay this keep you safe from harm." Two of the brothers made it home, while the other, Lt. Edsel J. McKnight of the United States Army Air Forces, was shot down off the coast of France. His Bible was mailed to the family but was lost sometime after. This month, his family finally got it back. Ava Coogan's family is from Albany, New York and they found the Bible in late December while going through their late matriarch‚Äôs belongings. On Jan. 11, Coogan met Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law and returned the Bible to her, allowing her to put it back in its rightful place, next to the ones his brothers brought back home from war. ‚ÄòI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages‚Äô Coogan‚Äôs uncle and mother found the Bible in a stack of books. Their mother, Rosanne Vartanian, died nearly 20 years ago but was a collector and loved garage sales. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just so random that my grandmother had the urge to pick that up,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúShe bought random things. There was no rhyme or reason to it. It was with a stack of other books.‚Äù Coogan decided to research the Bible and found out soldiers often took them to war. Some can be found in museums. ‚ÄúThe whole premise of it was that the metal cover on the front is like a hard shield,‚Äù Coogan told USA TODAY. ‚ÄúThey would put it in their coat pockets ‚Ä¶ like the front breast pocket ‚Ä¶ that cover would protect their heart from bullets.‚Äù Lt. McKnight‚Äôs name was also written in the Bible, said Coogan, who was drawn to the Bible for some reason. She couldn‚Äôt put it down, she recalled. ‚ÄúI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages,‚Äù she said. She noticed that the Bible‚Äôs front cover had a slice in it, almost like something was underneath it. She examined it more closely and found a piece of paper folded up inside. She asked her uncle for help, who carefully used a butter knife to get the slip of paper out. Once they retrieved the piece of paper from under the Bible‚Äôs cover, they saw that it was a plea for the Bible‚Äôs safe return to an address not too far away. Although there was no area code, there was a phone number listed, so the family added their own area code and called. ‚ÄúI was just hoping for the best,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúWe found out that number worked.‚Äù Lieutenant was shot down off the coast of France When Coogan called the number written in the note, she spoke to a woman named Fay, Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law. They organized a meetup on Jan. 11 to return the Bible to the family, who is from Porter Corners, part of Saratoga County in eastern New York. Lt. McKnight served in the U.S. Air Force‚Äôs 365th Fighter Group and 388th Fighter Squadron. He was flying in a Thunderbolt fighter aircraft in 1944 when he was shot down off the coast of France, [online records](https://rafbeaulieu.co.uk/honouring-the-airmen-of-raf-beaulieu/) show. Fay told Coogan and her family that Lt. McKnight has two brothers. All three of the brothers served in WWII. Fay‚Äôs husband, Ray, said his Bible saved his life. ‚ÄúHe got shot during the war and it hit where the Bible was, covering his heart, and the bullet went into his arm instead,‚Äù Coogan said. Once Lt. McKnight was killed, his belongings were shipped back home to the family. His sister-in-law had all three Bibles on a bookshelf on display. One day, the family was preparing to go to church. Her nephew borrowed the Bible, but knew it was so precious, the family decided to write a note with contact information in case it were ever lost. ‚ÄúHe didn't lose it,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúHe brought it back after church and I guess what happened is after someone passed in their family, they had an estate sale ‚Ä¶ and it just accidentally went out with a stack of books.‚Äù It ended up in Coogan‚Äôs grandmother‚Äôs hands, she said. Returning the Bible to the McKnight family was quite the enlightening experience, Coogan said. ‚ÄúThat was really cool because that's when we kind of got to hear their story,‚Äù she said.

author: Diciembre
title: ‚ÄúRegalaron la vida de mi hijo a esos delincuentes‚Äù, dice padre de Lince herido en Tacumb√∫ - √öltima Hora | Noticias de Paraguay y el mundo, las 24 horas. Noticias nacionales e internacionales, deportes, pol√≠tica. Noticias de √∫ltimo momento.
text: ‚ÄúRegalaron la vida de mi hijo a esos delincuentes‚Äù, dice padre de Lince herido en Tacumb√∫ El padre del agente del Grupo Lince, herido en el Operativo Veneratio en la Penitenciar√≠a Nacional de Tacumb√∫ d√≠as atr√°s, revel√≥ ahora que las autoridades de la Polic√≠a Nacional ‚Äúregalaron la vida de su hijo a los delincuentes‚Äù. El oficial ayudante Jos√© Rodrigo Gauto Cano, el agente del Grupo Lince que ingres√≥ dentro de la Penitenciar√≠a Nacional de Tacumb√∫ el 18 de diciembre pasado en el Operativo Veneratio, recibi√≥ este jueves su alta m√©dica. Su padre, Jos√© Gauto, manifest√≥ en conversaci√≥n con NPY que su hijo est√° muy bien, pese a no poder sostenerse. Record√≥ que estuvo en un ‚Äúmomento muy dif√≠cil con tres d√≠as en coma‚Äù y que gracias a las oraciones de las personas y a Dios, su hijo volvi√≥ a su casa. Lea m√°s: [Tres polic√≠as heridos en Tacumb√∫ contin√∫an en terapia intensiva](https://www.ultimahora.com/tres-policias-heridos-en-tacumbu-continuan-en-terapia-intensiva) Manifest√≥ que ocho d√≠as antes del Operativo Veneratio su hijo se recibi√≥ y que un d√≠a antes le coment√≥ que ten√≠a un operativo grande pero no sab√≠a en donde era. Dijo que uno de los jefes policiales le coment√≥ que el primer agente que entr√≥ en la c√°rcel de Tacumb√∫ fue su hijo y el segundo en ingresar fue el suboficial ayudante Mart√≠n Mendoza, quien salv√≥ la vida de su hijo. üó£Ô∏è"La vida de mi hijo le regalaron a esos delincuentes. Ellos cometieron un horror no error. Los Linces est√°n preparados para la calle, no para estas situaciones"‚Äî NPY Oficial (@npyoficial) üìå Expresa el padre del agente Jos√© Gauto quien fue herido tras el operativo [#Veneratio]en Tacumb√∫. ‚ô¶Ô∏è El mismo fue‚Ä¶ [pic.twitter.com/mcYkK1i8uJ] [December 28, 2023] ‚ÄúA mi hijo le dispararon en el ojo, en la cabeza. Mi hijo se iba caer de arriba entre los reos y el muchacho le ataj√≥, le estir√≥ y ah√≠ le dispararon al muchacho, me dijeron que con fusil le partieron la cabeza‚Äù, expres√≥. Nota relacionada: [Las identidades de los polic√≠as heridos en el Operativo Veneratio](https://www.ultimahora.com/las-identidades-de-los-policias-heridos-en-el-operativo-veneratio) Manifest√≥ que el pr√≥ximo martes conversar√° con el comandante de la Polic√≠a Nacional, Carlos Ben√≠tez, para llegar hasta las √∫ltimas instancias y que lo sucedido pueda seguir de ejemplo. Dijo que a los agentes del Grupo Lince les dieron escopetas que no funcionaban, carec√≠an de chalecos y ten√≠an balines de goma. ‚ÄúLe regalaron a mi hijo. La vida de mi hijo regalaron a esos delincuentes. Entraron sin condiciones, ellos son Linces, son para la calle, no est√°n preparados para estas incursiones, no estaban equipados‚Äù, lament√≥. Le puede interesar: [Video: As√≠ se ejecut√≥ el Operativo Veneratio para derrocar el imperio del clan Rotela en Tacumb√∫](https://www.ultimahora.com/video-asi-se-ejecuto-el-operativo-veneratio-para-derrocar-el-imperio-del-clan-rotela-en-tacumbu) Pidi√≥ a las autoridades mayor protecci√≥n para la Polic√≠a Nacional y que les brinden las herramientas necesarias para que puedan hacer bien su trabajo. ‚ÄúEllos est√°n preparados para las calles, no para estas incursiones, cometieron un horror, no error, hicieron todo mal el procedimiento, actuaron todo mal. Ojal√° sirva esto para corregir muchas cosas‚Äù, concluy√≥. Un total de 708 presos fueron trasladados a diferentes c√°rceles del pa√≠s, en el marco del operativo Veneratio, que uni√≥ a las fuerzas policiales y militares este lunes para recuperar el control del penal de Tacumb√∫, donde los presos ten√≠an fusiles, armas cortas, y hasta dinamita.

author: Amandalina Letterio
title: London-based bank donates $50,000 to Sally Ann
text: [Skip to main content](#main) London-based bank donates $50,000 to Sally Ann A London, Ont.-based financial institution has made a significant contribution to the Salvation Army. VersaBank has named the Salvation Army its newest flagship charity, donating $50,000. Salvation Army officials said the money actually came in back in October, and was matched by an anonymous donor. They estimate one in five Canadians are dealing with food insecurity right now. Last year, food banks and support programs served more than five million people a month. That number is expected to grow by 60 per cent for this year. VersaBank's President and CEO is encouraging other organizations to support similar initiatives. "There's a lot of need, particularly in the city of London for food and accommodation for homeless people,‚Äù David Taylor told CTV News. ‚ÄúThankfully in the past, we had a hand in creating the centre of hope for the Salvation Army, and we just thought it just sort of moves any organization that's making a few dollars to give back as best we can to help out the less fortunate people particularly around Christmas time,‚Äù he said.
